dc:description:
FGFR1 has been described in relation to autosomal dominant Osteoglophonic Dysplasia (OD) as early as 2005 by White et al. (PMID: 15625620). Clinical phenotypes of OD include brachy-turricephaly, midface hypoplasia, short stature, short/broad hands and feet, and failure to thrive due to feeding and respiratory difficulties in some cases. The mechanism of disease is dominant-positive gain of function variants, causing increased signalling of the FGFR1 protein (PMID: 15625620). At least 5 unique missense variants have been reported in the literature. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, of 8 probands from 5 publications (PMIDs: 15625620, 31319224, 29147600, 20236123, 16470795). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Craniofacial Malformations Gene Curation Expert Panel on 2/25/2021. 
Gene Clinical Validity Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) – Version 8.

evidence.dc:description: Confirmed de novo variant in patient without detailed radiographs nor functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: White Patient 4
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequence analysis of FGFR1 in patient and parents- absent from parents.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: prominent eyes, a short nose, palpable cranial sutures, pansutural craniosynostosis, pectus excavatum, delayed tooth eruption growth impairment/short stature, bilateral flexion contractures of her fingers. Furthermore, a skeletal survey of patient 4 showed multiple lesions in the metaphyseal regions of the long bones.

evidence.dc:description: Confirmed de novo variant in patient with consistent phenotypes and radiograph, no functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: White Patient 3
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of FGFR1 to identify variant in proband, and confirm absence in parents.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Severe craniosynostosis, midface hypoplasia, right choanal atresia, mild rhizomelic shortening of the limbs (progressive), severe femur metaphyseal lesions, marked demineralization of the long bones, the mandible, and the maxilla, swelling that arose from the lower gums, with a histologic appearance resembling giant-cell granulomata, hypophosphatemic
evidence.previousTestingDescription: DNA analysis was negative for Pfeiffer syndrome mutations and Muenke and Saethre-Chotzen syndromes mutations

evidence.dc:description: Variant in patient with consistent phenotypes and radiographs.

evidence.rdfs:label: Marzin Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: WES of the three affected family members
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Walking difficulties, several symmetrical metaphyseal radiolucent lesions in long bones, NO craniosynostosis, non-ossifying fibroma, lower limb pain, one left humerus fracture. At 7 years of age, delayed development and eruption of first permanent molars, delayed radiculogenesis of erupted permanent incisors, two supernumerary teeth, absence of primary mandibular second molars. At 8 years of age, hypertelorism, epicanthus, mandibular and maxillary protrusion, high-arched palate, gingival hypertrophy, low-set ears.

evidence.dc:description: No parental information, no supporting functional nor radiograph evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Sow Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Short stature, mandibular prognathism, midfacial hypoplasia, hypertelorism, right eye hypertropia, an everted nose with a depressed nasal bridge, brachydactyly with a single palmar crease, fusion of the proximal interphalangeal joints in all four limbs, bilateral rhizomelic shortening of the humerus and femur, short metacarpals with fusion of proximal and middle phalanx, bilateral enlargement of the metaphysis of distal femur, anterior beaking of lumbar vertebral body, craniosynostosis, small midface and prognathic mandible, giant cell lesions of right maxilla and left mandible.

evidence.rdfs:label: White Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of all exons in FGFR1–4, as well as the novel decoy receptor gene FGFR5.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: craniosynostosis, severe nasal maxillary hypoplasia, telecanthus, and prominent supraorbital ridge, growth impairment/short stature, hypophosphatemic.

evidence.dc:description: Variant in proband with consistent phenotypes and with radiographs (Beighton et al.)

evidence.rdfs:label: Farrow Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: All exons of FGFR1 were analyzed. Genetic analysis performed by Farrow et al.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Presented at 10 years of age with asymmetrical frontal bossing, hypertelorism, prognathism, anteverted nostrils, unerupted teeth, craniosynostosis, short stature- clinical report from Beighton et al. (including radiographs)
At 39 yrs, detailed medical and oro-dental evaluation revealed that she was ambulatory, had no weakness, no outward signs of severe hypophosphatemia- clinical report from Roberts et al.

evidence.dc:description: No parental sequencing, no radiographs, no functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Farrow Patient 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Analysis of all exons of FGFR1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: severe craniosynostosis, midface hypoplasia, and rhizomelic limb shortening. Radiographs (not shown in paper): pronounced femoral metaphyseal lesions

evidence.dc:description: Variant in proband with consistent phenotypes and with radiographs.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kuthiroly Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Scope of sequencing not specified but at least all of FGFR1.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Short stature, turribrachycephaly, hypertelorism, prominent supraorbital ridge, flat nasal bridge, bilateral low-set, posteriorly rotated pinnae, high-arched palate, rhizomelic shortening of the limbs, brachydactyly of hands and feet, stubby fingers and toes, varus deformity of both lower tibia, abnormal dentition, severe gum hypertrophy, turribrachycephaly, enlarged sella, flattening of forehead, midfacial hypoplasia, prognathism, bell-shaped thorax with down-slanting broad ribs, severe brachydactyly with very short metacarpals and phalanges, mild flattening of the thoracic vertebrae, shortened long bones, epiphyseal lucencies, nonossifying fibromas
